question: Changing HTML Elements
answer:
### **JavaScript DOM Properties and Methods for Modifying HTML Elements** In JavaScript, the **DOM (Document Object Model)** provides **properties and methods** to dynamically **modify content, attributes, and styles** of HTML elements. --- ## **üìå DOM Properties** DOM **properties** allow you to **get or set values** of HTML elements. | **Property** | **Description** | |-------------|----------------| | `element.innerHTML = "New content";` | Changes the **HTML content** inside an element. | | `element.attribute = "new value";` | Changes an **attribute value** of an element (e.g., `src`, `href`, `id`). | | `element.style.property = "new style";` | Changes an element's **CSS style** dynamically. | ### **Example: Modifying Content, Attributes, and Styles** ```html

This is a paragraph.

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `innerHTML` **modifies** the text inside the `

` tag. ‚úî `.src = "image2.jpg"` **changes** the image source. ‚úî `.style.color = "red"` **updates** the text color. --- ## **üìå DOM Methods** DOM **methods** perform actions on elements. | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `element.setAttribute(attribute, value);` | Changes the **attribute value** of an HTML element. | ### **Example: Using `setAttribute()` to Modify Attributes** ```html ``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `setAttribute("disabled", "true")` **disables** the button. ‚úî `.innerHTML = "Updated!"` **updates the button text**. ‚úî `.style.backgroundColor = "blue"` **changes the button color**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Feature** | **Usage** | **Example** | |------------|----------|-------------| | **Modify Content** | `element.innerHTML = "New content";` | `document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = "Hello!";` | | **Modify Attributes** | `element.attribute = "new value";` | `document.getElementById("img").src = "new.jpg";` | | **Modify Style** | `element.style.property = "new style";` | `document.getElementById("demo").style.color = "blue";` | | **Set Attributes** | `element.setAttribute("attribute", "value");` | `element.setAttribute("class", "highlight");` | üöÄ **Using these DOM properties and methods makes web pages dynamic and interactive!**

subject: DOM document
question: Adding and Deleting Elements
answer:
### **JavaScript DOM Methods for Creating, Modifying, and Removing Elements** The **Document Object Model (DOM)** provides methods to **dynamically create, add, modify, or remove** HTML elements using JavaScript. --- ## **üìå Common DOM Methods for Element Manipulation** | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `document.createElement(element)` | Creates a new **HTML element**. | | `document.removeChild(element)` | Removes an existing **child element** from its parent. | | `document.appendChild(element)` | Adds a **new element** as a child of an existing element. | | `document.replaceChild(newElement, oldElement)` | Replaces an **existing element** with a **new element**. | | `document.write(text)` | Writes **directly into the HTML document** (Not recommended). | --- ## **üìå Example 1: Creating and Adding an Element (`createElement` + `appendChild`)** ```html
``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.createElement("p")` ‚Üí Creates a **new paragraph (`

`)** element. ‚úî `newPara.innerHTML = "Text"` ‚Üí Sets the text inside the new element. ‚úî `appendChild(newPara)` ‚Üí Adds the new `

` element inside `#container`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Removing an Element (`removeChild`)** ```html

  • Item 1
  • Item 2 (Click to Remove)
  • Item 3
``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `this.parentNode.removeChild(this)` ‚Üí Removes **Item 2** when clicked. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Replacing an Element (`replaceChild`)** ```html
  • Old Item
``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `createElement("li")` ‚Üí Creates a new list item. ‚úî `replaceChild(newItem, oldItem)` ‚Üí Replaces **"Old Item"** with **"New Item"**. --- ## **üìå Example 4: Writing Directly to the Document (`document.write`)** ```html ``` ### **‚ö†Ô∏è Warning**: - **`document.write()` replaces the entire page** if used **after the page loads**. - It is **not recommended** for modern JavaScript applications. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `createElement("tag")` | Creates a new element. | `document.createElement("p");` | | `appendChild(node)` | Adds an element inside another. | `parent.appendChild(child);` | | `removeChild(node)` | Removes an element. | `parent.removeChild(child);` | | `replaceChild(new, old)` | Replaces an existing element. | `parent.replaceChild(newElement, oldElement);` | | `document.write("text")` | Writes directly to the document. ‚ö†Ô∏è Not recommended. | `document.write("Hello!");` | üöÄ **Mastering these methods** allows you to dynamically **create, modify, and remove elements**, making your web pages interactive and dynamic!

subject: DOM document
question: Adding Events Handlers
answer:
### **Adding an `onclick` Event Handler in JavaScript Using `document.getElementById()`** The **`onclick` event** in JavaScript is used to execute code when an element is clicked. You can attach an event handler dynamically using `document.getElementById(id).onclick`. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js document.getElementById("elementID").onclick = function() { // Code to execute when the element is clicked }; ``` - `getElementById("elementID")` ‚Üí Selects the element with the given `id`. - `.onclick = function() {}` ‚Üí Assigns an **anonymous function** to handle the click event. --- ## **üìå Example: Changing Text When Button is Clicked** ```html

Click the button to change this text.

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.getElementById("myButton")` ‚Üí Selects the button. ‚úî `.onclick = function() {}` ‚Üí Attaches a click event to the button. ‚úî `document.getElementById("text").innerHTML = "Text changed!";` ‚Üí Modifies the paragraph content on click. --- ## **üìå Example: Changing Background Color on Click** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **changes the background color** of the page. --- ## **üìå Alternative: Using `addEventListener()` (Recommended)** While `onclick` works fine, a better practice is to use **`addEventListener()`**, which allows multiple event listeners for the same event. ```js document.getElementById("myButton").addEventListener("click", function() { document.getElementById("text").innerHTML = "Text changed!"; }); ``` ‚úî `addEventListener("click", function)` is **more flexible** than `.onclick`, as it allows multiple event listeners. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `element.onclick = function() {}` | Attaches a click event handler to an element. | | `element.addEventListener("click", function() {})` | Recommended way to add click events (supports multiple listeners). | üöÄ **Using JavaScript events dynamically makes web pages interactive and engaging!**

question: Finding HTML Objects
answer:
### **HTML DOM Properties Overview (Level 1 & Level 3)** The **HTML DOM (Document Object Model)** provides properties and methods to access and manipulate web pages. The **DOM Levels** indicate the evolution of these properties, with **DOM Level 1 (1998)** introducing the core objects and **DOM Level 3** adding more functionalities. --- ## **üìå Important HTML DOM Properties** Below is a categorized summary of key **DOM Level 1 and Level 3** properties. ### **üìå DOM Level 1 Properties (Introduced in 1998)** | Property | Description | |----------|-------------| | `document.anchors` | Returns all `` elements **with a `name` attribute**. | | `document.applets` | Returns all `` elements (**Deprecated in HTML5**). | | `document.body` | Returns the `` element of the document. | | `document.cookie` | Returns the document's **cookies**. | | `document.domain` | Returns the **domain name** of the web page. | | `document.forms` | Returns a **collection of all `
` elements** in the document. | | `document.images` | Returns a **collection of all `` elements**. | | `document.links` | Returns all `` and `` elements **that have an `href` attribute**. | | `document.referrer` | Returns the **URL of the referrer** (the previous page that linked to the document). | | `document.title` | Returns the document‚Äôs `` tag. | | `document.URL` | Returns the **full URL** of the document. | --- ### **üìå DOM Level 3 Properties (Enhancements in Later Versions)** | Property | Description | |----------|-------------| | `document.baseURI` | Returns the **absolute base URI** of the document. | | `document.doctype` | Returns the **document's DOCTYPE**. | | `document.documentElement` | Returns the `<html>` element. | | `document.documentMode` | Returns the **browser rendering mode** (quirks or standards mode). | | `document.documentURI` | Returns the **URI of the document**. | | `document.embeds` | Returns a **collection of all `<embed>` elements**. | | `document.head` | Returns the `<head>` element of the document. | | `document.implementation` | Returns the **DOM implementation object**. | | `document.inputEncoding` | Returns the **character encoding** of the document. | | `document.lastModified` | Returns the **last modified date** of the document. | | `document.readyState` | Returns the **current loading status** (`loading`, `interactive`, `complete`). | | `document.scripts` | Returns a **collection of all `<script>` elements**. | | `document.strictErrorChecking` | Indicates whether **strict error checking is enabled** (Boolean). | --- ## **üìå Examples of Common DOM Properties** ### **1Ô∏è‚É£ Get Document Title (`document.title`)** ```js console.log(document.title); // Returns the title of the document ``` ### **2Ô∏è‚É£ Get All Images (`document.images`)** ```js let images = document.images; console.log(images.length); // Number of images on the page ``` ### **3Ô∏è‚É£ Get Last Modified Date (`document.lastModified`)** ```js console.log("Last Modified: " + document.lastModified); ``` ### **4Ô∏è‚É£ Get the Full Page URL (`document.URL`)** ```js console.log(document.URL); // Returns the full URL of the current page ``` ### **5Ô∏è‚É£ Check Page Loading State (`document.readyState`)** ```js console.log(document.readyState); // Returns "loading", "interactive", or "complete" ``` --- ## **üìå Summary** | **DOM Level** | **Properties** | **Examples** | |--------------|---------------|-------------| | **DOM 1** | `document.body`, `document.forms`, `document.images`, `document.title`, `document.URL` | Access the `<body>` element, get all forms/images, check title & URL. | | **DOM 3** | `document.doctype`, `document.head`, `document.readyState`, `document.lastModified` | Get DOCTYPE, check page load status, last modified date. | üöÄ **Understanding DOM properties** allows developers to dynamically **access and manipulate web pages** using JavaScript!</body></html>

subject: DOM elements
question: Finding HTML Element by Id
answer:
### **Finding an HTML Element by ID Using `document.getElementById()`** The **easiest way** to **select an HTML element** in the DOM is by using the **`document.getElementById()`** method. It returns the **first matching element** with the given `id`, or `null` if no matching element exists. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js var myElement = document.getElementById("intro"); ``` - `document.getElementById("intro")` ‚Üí Searches for an element with `id="intro"`. - If found, `myElement` holds the **element object**. - If not found, `myElement` is `null`. --- ## **üìå Example: Selecting an Element by ID** ```html

Hello, this is an introduction!

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî **Selects the `

` element** with `id="intro"`. ‚úî **Changes its content** when the button is clicked. ‚úî **Checks if the element exists** before modifying it (`if (myElement) {}`). --- ## **üìå Example: Checking If an Element Exists** If the element does not exist, `getElementById()` returns `null`, which can cause errors if not handled properly. ```js var element = document.getElementById("nonExistent"); if (element === null) { console.log("Element not found!"); } else { console.log("Element found:", element); } ``` ‚úî Ensures the element **exists before accessing its properties**. --- ## **üìå When to Use `getElementById()`** ‚úî When selecting **a single unique element** (`id` must be unique). ‚úî When **modifying content dynamically** (e.g., updating text, changing styles). ‚úî When **checking for element existence** before performing actions. üöÄ **Mastering `document.getElementById()`** helps in quickly accessing and manipulating HTML elements!

question: Finding HTML Elements by Tag Name
answer:
### **Finding HTML Elements Using `getElementsByTagName()` in JavaScript** The **`document.getElementsByTagName()`** method allows you to **select multiple elements** by their **tag name** (e.g., `p`, `div`, `span`). This method returns a **collection (HTMLCollection)** of matching elements. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js var elements = document.getElementsByTagName("tagName"); ``` - Returns a **collection (HTMLCollection)** of all elements with the specified tag name. - If no matching elements are found, it returns an **empty collection**. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Finding All `

` Elements** ```html

Paragraph 1

Paragraph 2

Paragraph 3

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.getElementsByTagName("p")` **selects all `

` elements**. ‚úî The loop **iterates through the collection** and applies a style change. ‚úî Clicking the button **highlights all paragraphs**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Finding `

` Elements Inside a Specific Element** Instead of selecting all `

` elements in the document, you can **narrow the search** to a specific container. ```html

Main Paragraph 1

Main Paragraph 2

Secondary Paragraph

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.getElementById("main")` **selects the `
` with `id="main"`**. ‚úî `.getElementsByTagName("p")` **finds all `

` elements inside** the `main` div. ‚úî Clicking the button **only changes the text color of paragraphs inside `main`**, leaving other paragraphs unaffected. --- ## **üìå `getElementsByTagName()` vs. `querySelectorAll()`** While `getElementsByTagName()` is useful, **`querySelectorAll()`** provides more flexibility by allowing **CSS selectors**. | Method | Returns | Supports CSS Selectors? | |--------|---------|------------------------| | `getElementsByTagName("tag")` | **HTMLCollection** (live) | ‚ùå No | | `querySelectorAll("tag")` | **NodeList** (static) | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úî **Use `getElementsByTagName()` when you need a live collection of elements.** ‚úî **Use `querySelectorAll()` when selecting elements with more complex CSS selectors.** --- ### **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `document.getElementsByTagName("p")` | Selects **all** `

` elements in the document. | | `element.getElementsByTagName("p")` | Selects `

` elements **inside a specific element**. | üöÄ **Using `getElementsByTagName()` effectively helps you manipulate groups of elements dynamically!**

subject: DOM elements
question: Finding HTML Elements by Class Name
answer:
### **Finding Elements by Class Name Using `getElementsByClassName()` in JavaScript** The **`document.getElementsByClassName()`** method allows you to **select multiple elements** by their **class name**. It returns an **HTMLCollection** of all elements that share the specified class. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js var elements = document.getElementsByClassName("className"); ``` - **Returns** an **HTMLCollection** (a live collection of matching elements). - **If no elements match**, it returns an **empty collection**. - **Works in modern browsers**, but **not supported in Internet Explorer 8 or earlier**. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Selecting All Elements with a Specific Class** ```html

First intro paragraph.

Second intro paragraph.

Another paragraph.

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.getElementsByClassName("intro")` selects **all** elements with `class="intro"`. ‚úî The **loop iterates** through the collection and **applies a yellow background**. ‚úî Clicking the button **highlights only elements with the `"intro"` class**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Finding Elements Inside a Specific Container** Instead of searching the **entire document**, you can limit the search to a **specific parent element**. ```html

Inside content div.

Another intro inside content.

Outside content div.

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.getElementById("content")` **selects the `
`** with `id="content"`. ‚úî `.getElementsByClassName("intro")` finds **only elements inside `content`**. ‚úî Clicking the button **only changes the text color of paragraphs inside `content`**, leaving other `.intro` elements unchanged. --- ## **üìå `getElementsByClassName()` vs. `querySelectorAll()`** Since `getElementsByClassName()` is **not supported in Internet Explorer 8 or earlier**, an alternative is **`querySelectorAll()`**. | Method | Returns | Supports IE8? | |--------|---------|--------------| | `getElementsByClassName("class")` | **HTMLCollection** (live) | ‚ùå No | | `querySelectorAll(".class")` | **NodeList** (static) | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úî **Use `querySelectorAll(".class")`** if you need compatibility with older browsers. ### **Example Using `querySelectorAll()`** ```js var elements = document.querySelectorAll(".intro"); ``` - This selects **all elements** with `class="intro"`, just like `getElementsByClassName()` but works in **all modern browsers**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `document.getElementsByClassName("class")` | Selects **all** elements with the given class. | | `element.getElementsByClassName("class")` | Selects elements **inside a specific element**. | | `document.querySelectorAll(".class")` | Alternative that works in **older browsers**. | üöÄ **Using `getElementsByClassName()` efficiently helps in selecting multiple elements dynamically and making web pages interactive!**

question: Finding HTML Elements by CSS Selectors
answer:
### **Using `querySelectorAll()` to Select Elements in JavaScript** The **`querySelectorAll()`** method allows you to **select multiple elements** that match a specified **CSS selector**. Unlike `getElementById()` or `getElementsByClassName()`, **this method supports all CSS selectors**, including **tag names, class names, attributes, and more**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js var elements = document.querySelectorAll("CSS selector"); ``` - **Returns a `NodeList`** (a static list of elements matching the selector). - **If no elements match**, it returns an **empty NodeList**. - **Not supported in Internet Explorer 8 or earlier**. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Selecting All `

` Elements with a Class** ```html

Paragraph 1 with class intro.

Paragraph 2 with class intro.

Another paragraph without class.

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.querySelectorAll("p.intro")` selects **all `

` elements with class `"intro"`**. ‚úî The loop applies a **yellow background** to each selected element. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Selecting Elements Using Different CSS Selectors** ### **Selecting Elements by ID, Class, and Attributes** ```js document.querySelectorAll("#myId"); // Selects the element with id="myId" document.querySelectorAll(".myClass"); // Selects all elements with class="myClass" document.querySelectorAll("input[type='text']"); // Selects all elements with type="text" document.querySelectorAll("div > p"); // Selects all

elements that are direct children of a

``` --- ## **üìå Example 3: Selecting Elements Inside a Specific Container** ```html

Inside container

Another inside container

Outside container

``` ‚úî **Only paragraphs inside `#container` with class `"intro"` are affected**. --- ## **üìå `querySelectorAll()` vs. `getElementsByClassName()`** | Method | Returns | Supports CSS Selectors? | Live or Static Collection? | |--------|---------|------------------------|----------------------------| | `getElementsByClassName("class")` | **HTMLCollection** | ‚ùå No | **Live** | | `querySelectorAll(".class")` | **NodeList** | ‚úÖ Yes | **Static** | ### **Key Differences**: - `querySelectorAll()` **supports all CSS selectors** (`.class`, `#id`, `[attribute]`, `:nth-child()`, etc.). - `getElementsByClassName()` only works for **class names**. - `querySelectorAll()` returns a **static NodeList** (does not update if elements are added/removed later). - `getElementsByClassName()` returns a **live HTMLCollection** (updates dynamically). --- ## **üìå Summary** ‚úî **`querySelectorAll()` selects multiple elements matching a CSS selector**. ‚úî **Works with any valid CSS selector**, including **classes, IDs, attributes, and child selectors**. ‚úî **Returns a `NodeList` (not live)**, meaning it doesn‚Äôt update when elements are added or removed dynamically. ‚úî **Not supported in Internet Explorer 8 or earlier** (use `getElementsByClassName()` for compatibility). üöÄ **Using `querySelectorAll()` provides a powerful and flexible way to select multiple elements dynamically!**

answer:
### **Accessing Forms and Their Elements Using `document.forms` in JavaScript** The **`document.forms`** collection allows you to access **all `
` elements** in an HTML document. Using this, you can iterate through form elements and retrieve their values dynamically. --- ## **üìå Example: Accessing Form Elements by ID** This example retrieves all input values from a form with `id="frm1"` and displays them. ```html First name:
Last name:
Age:

``` ### **Explanation**: ‚úî `document.forms["frm1"]` ‚Üí Selects the form with `id="frm1"`. ‚úî `x.elements[i].value` ‚Üí Retrieves each form element‚Äôs value. ‚úî The values are displayed inside the `

` tag with `id="demo"`. --- ## **üìå Alternative: Using `querySelector` for Better Selection** While `document.forms` works well, `document.querySelector()` can also be used for better flexibility. ```js var x = document.querySelector("#frm1"); ``` ‚úî This **selects the form directly using CSS selectors**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | |------------|----------------| | `document.forms` | Returns a collection of all forms in the document. | | `document.forms["frmID"]` | Retrieves a specific form by its `id` or `name`. | | `form.elements[i]` | Accesses individual form elements. | | `form.elements[i].value` | Retrieves the value of an input field. | üöÄ **Using `document.forms` helps efficiently retrieve and manipulate form data dynamically!**

question: Changing the HTML Output Stream
answer:
### **Using `document.write()` in JavaScript** The **`document.write()`** method allows JavaScript to **directly write content into the HTML document**. While it can be useful for quickly inserting content during page loading, it has significant **limitations**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js document.write("Hello, World!"); ``` - The above line **writes directly** into the HTML page. --- ## **üìå Example: Writing the Current Date** ```html ``` ‚úî This **displays the current date** inside the page. --- ## **‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: `document.write()` Overwrites the Entire Page** Using `document.write()` **after the page has loaded** will erase all existing content. ### **Example: `document.write()` Overwriting Page Content** ```html

Original Content

``` ‚úî **Clicking the button clears everything** and replaces it with `"All content is erased!"`. --- ## **üìå When to Avoid `document.write()`** ‚ùå **Never use it after the page is loaded** ‚Üí It erases the entire document. ‚ùå **Not recommended for dynamic updates** ‚Üí Use `innerHTML` or `appendChild()` instead. ‚ùå **Not suitable for modern JavaScript practices** ‚Üí Avoid in interactive web applications. --- ## **üìå Alternative: Using `innerHTML` Instead of `document.write()`** A better approach is **modifying an existing element** using `.innerHTML`. ### **Example: Updating Content Without Overwriting** ```html

Original text

``` ‚úî The button updates text **without erasing the page**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Recommended?** | |------------|----------------|-----------------| | `document.write("text")` | Writes directly to the document **(can erase content if used after load)** | ‚ùå No | | `element.innerHTML = "text"` | Updates the content of an existing element | ‚úÖ Yes | | `document.createElement()` + `appendChild()` | Dynamically adds new elements | ‚úÖ Yes | üöÄ **Use `document.write()` only for quick debugging, but avoid it in modern web development!**

subject: DOM HTML
question: Changing HTML Content
answer:
### **Modifying HTML Content Using `innerHTML` in JavaScript** The **easiest way** to modify the content of an HTML element is by using the **`innerHTML` property**. This allows JavaScript to **dynamically update** the HTML content inside an element. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js document.getElementById("elementID").innerHTML = "New HTML content"; ``` - **`getElementById("elementID")`** ‚Üí Selects the HTML element by `id`. - **`.innerHTML`** ‚Üí Sets or retrieves the **HTML content** inside the element. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Changing Text Inside a `

` Element** ```html

Original Text

``` ‚úî Clicking the button **updates the paragraph's content**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Adding New HTML Content** You can also **insert HTML elements** using `innerHTML`. ```html
This is a div.
``` ‚úî This **replaces** the content inside `
` with a new `

` element. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Appending Content Without Overwriting** Using **`innerHTML +=`** allows you to **append content instead of replacing** it. ```js document.getElementById("container").innerHTML += "

Additional content.

"; ``` --- ## **‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Avoid `innerHTML` for User Input** Using `innerHTML` with **user-generated content** can lead to **Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks**. ‚úî **Use `textContent` instead** to insert text safely: ```js document.getElementById("demo").textContent = "Safe text content."; ``` üöÄ **`textContent` does not interpret HTML**, making it a safer alternative. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Property** | **Description** | **Example** | |-------------|----------------|-------------| | `innerHTML` | **Gets or sets** an element‚Äôs HTML content | `element.innerHTML = "New Content";` | | `textContent` | **Gets or sets text only** (ignores HTML) | `element.textContent = "Plain text";` | üöÄ **Use `innerHTML` for inserting HTML dynamically, but always sanitize input to prevent security risks!**

subject: DOM HTML
question: Changing the Value of an Attribute
answer: ### **Modifying HTML Attributes Using JavaScript** In JavaScript, you can change the **value of an HTML attribute** using the **`attribute` property** or the **`setAttribute()` method**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js document.getElementById("elementID").attribute = "newValue"; ``` - **`getElementById("elementID")`** ‚Üí Selects the HTML element by `id`. - **`attribute = "newValue"`** ‚Üí Updates the value of the specified attribute. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Changing an Image `src` Attribute** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **updates the image source** from `image1.jpg` to `image2.jpg`. --- ## **üìå Alternative: Using `setAttribute()`** Instead of directly modifying properties, you can use **`setAttribute()`**, which works for any attribute. ### **Example 2: Changing an Attribute Using `setAttribute()`** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **disables itself** using `setAttribute("disabled", "true")`. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Changing Multiple Attributes** You can modify multiple attributes at once. ```js let link = document.getElementById("myLink"); link.href = "https://www.google.com"; link.target = "_blank"; // Opens in a new tab link.title = "Go to Google"; ``` --- ## **üìå `setAttribute()` vs. Direct Property Assignment** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `element.attribute = value;` | Works for **common attributes** (like `src`, `href`, `id`). | `element.src = "newImage.jpg";` | | `element.setAttribute(name, value);` | Works for **any attribute**, even custom ones. | `element.setAttribute("data-value", "123");` | üöÄ **Use `setAttribute()` when modifying custom attributes, and direct property assignment for common attributes like `src`, `href`, or `class`.**

subject: DOM CSS
question: Changing HTML Style
answer:
### **Modifying an HTML Element‚Äôs Style Using JavaScript** In JavaScript, you can dynamically change the **CSS styles** of an HTML element using the **`style` property**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js document.getElementById("elementID").style.property = "newStyle"; ``` - **`getElementById("elementID")`** ‚Üí Selects the HTML element by `id`. - **`.style.property = "newStyle"`** ‚Üí Updates the specified CSS property. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Changing Text Color** ```html

This is a paragraph.

``` ‚úî Clicking the button **changes the text color** of the paragraph to red. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Changing Background Color** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **changes the page background** to light blue. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Changing Multiple Styles** You can modify **multiple CSS properties** by assigning each property separately. ```js document.getElementById("box").style.width = "200px"; document.getElementById("box").style.height = "100px"; document.getElementById("box").style.backgroundColor = "yellow"; ``` Or, use **`cssText`** to update multiple styles at once: ```js document.getElementById("box").style.cssText = "width: 200px; height: 100px; background-color: yellow;"; ``` --- ## **üìå Example 4: Toggling Styles with JavaScript** You can **toggle styles dynamically** using JavaScript. ```html

Click the button to toggle text color.

``` ‚úî Clicking the button **toggles the text color** between black and blue. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `element.style.property = "value";` | Changes a **single CSS property**. | `element.style.color = "red";` | | `element.style.cssText = "prop: value; prop: value;"` | Changes **multiple styles** at once. | `element.style.cssText = "color: blue; font-size: 20px;"` | üöÄ **Using JavaScript to modify styles dynamically enhances interactivity and user experience on web pages!**

This makes web pages **interactive** and **dynamic**. --- ## **üìå How to Execute JavaScript on Events** You can execute JavaScript **in different ways** when an event occurs: 1. **Inline HTML Event Attributes** (Not recommended for complex scripts) 2. **JavaScript Event Properties** 3. **`addEventListener()` Method** (Recommended) --- ## **üìå Example: Using `onclick` to Run JavaScript** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **triggers an alert**. --- ## **üìå Common HTML Events** | **Event** | **Description** | **Example Trigger** | |-----------|----------------|---------------------| | `onclick` | When an element is clicked. | ` ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **updates the paragraph text**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Using `onmouseover` to Change Background** ```html

Hover over me!

``` ‚úî When the mouse **hovers over the text**, the **background turns yellow**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Using `onchange` to Detect Input Changes** ```html

``` ‚úî When the user **types something and moves out of the input field**, the paragraph updates. --- ## **üìå Recommended: Using `addEventListener()`** Instead of inline attributes, use **`addEventListener()`**, which is more flexible. ```js document.getElementById("myButton").addEventListener("click", function() { alert("Button Clicked!"); }); ``` ‚úî This keeps HTML **clean** and allows **multiple event listeners** on the same element. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | **Inline Event Attribute** | Adds an event directly in HTML (**not recommended for complex scripts**). | `` | | **Event Property** | Assigns an event in JavaScript (**overwrites previous event**). | `element.onclick = function() {...}` | | **`addEventListener()`** | Attaches multiple event listeners (**recommended approach**). | `element.addEventListener("click", function() {...})` | üöÄ **Mastering event handling in JavaScript** allows for creating **dynamic, interactive, and responsive web pages!**

question: The onload and onunload Events
answer:
### **Using `onload` and `onunload` Events in JavaScript**

The **`onload` and `onunload`** events allow JavaScript to execute code when a user **enters or leaves** a web page.

---

## **üìå `onload` Event**
- **Triggered when a webpage has fully loaded**.
- Useful for:
  - Running scripts **after all content** (HTML, images, styles) has loaded.
  - Checking **browser type** and loading different versions of a page.
  - **Handling cookies** when the page loads.

### **Example 1: Running a Function When the Page Loads**
```html








```
‚úî When the page loads, an **alert message appears**.

---

## **üìå `onunload` Event**
- **Triggered when the user leaves the page** (navigating away or closing the browser).
- Useful for:
  - Saving **user data before exit**.
  - **Confirming exit actions**.

### **Example 2: Alerting When the User Leaves**
```html








```
‚úî The **alert appears when the user leaves the page**.

---

## **üìå Example 3: Checking Browser Type with `onload`**
You can check the **visitor‚Äôs browser type** when the page loads.

```html



```
‚úî **Detects the browser type** and alerts the user.

---

## **üìå Example 4: Checking Cookies with `onload`**
Cookies can store **user preferences** and load them when the page opens.

```html



```
‚úî **Checks if cookies are enabled** and alerts the user.

---

## **üìå Alternative: Using `addEventListener()` for `onload`**
Instead of writing `onload` inside ``, use JavaScript:

```js
window.addEventListener("load", function() {
    alert("Page has loaded successfully!");
});
```
‚úî **Keeps HTML clean** and allows multiple event listeners.

---

## **üìå Summary**
| **Event** | **Triggers When...** | **Common Uses** |
|-----------|----------------------|----------------|
| **`onload`** | The page **fully loads** | Check **browser type**, **load cookies**, run scripts **after page load**. |
| **`onunload`** | The user **leaves the page** | Save user data, **confirm exit actions**, clean up resources. |

üöÄ **Using `onload` and `onunload` helps improve user experience by handling page load events efficiently!**

### **Using `onmouseover` and `onmouseout` Events in JavaScript** The **`onmouseover` and `onmouseout`** events allow JavaScript to detect when the mouse **enters** (`onmouseover`) or **leaves** (`onmouseout`) an element. These events are commonly used for **hover effects, tooltips, and dynamic styling**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```html element.onmouseover = function() { /* Code when mouse enters */ }; element.onmouseout = function() { /* Code when mouse leaves */ }; ``` - **`onmouseover`** ‚Üí Triggers when the mouse enters the element. - **`onmouseout`** ‚Üí Triggers when the mouse leaves the element. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Changing Background Color on Hover** ```html

Hover over me!

``` ‚úî **When the user hovers over the text, the background turns yellow; when they leave, it resets.** --- ## **üìå Example 2: Displaying a Tooltip on Hover** ```html

Hover over me for info!

This is additional information. ``` ‚úî **When the user hovers, extra information appears; when they move away, it disappears.** --- ## **üìå Example 3: Using `addEventListener()` (Recommended)** Instead of using `onmouseover` and `onmouseout` in HTML, you can assign them using JavaScript. ```html

Hover over me!

``` ‚úî **Keeps HTML clean and allows multiple event listeners on the same element.** --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Event** | **Description** | **Example** | |-----------|----------------|-------------| | `onmouseover` | Triggers when the mouse enters an element. | `element.onmouseover = function() {...};` | | `onmouseout` | Triggers when the mouse leaves an element. | `element.onmouseout = function() {...};` | üöÄ **Using hover events improves interactivity and user experience on web pages!**

subject: DOM events
question: The onmousedown, onmouseup and onclick Events
answer:
### **Understanding `onmousedown`, `onmouseup`, and `onclick` Events in JavaScript**

A **mouse click** consists of three key events:
1. **`onmousedown`** ‚Üí Fires when the mouse button is **pressed down**.
2. **`onmouseup`** ‚Üí Fires when the mouse button is **released**.
3. **`onclick`** ‚Üí Fires when the **click action is completed** (after both `mousedown` and `mouseup`).

---

## **üìå Event Execution Order**
1Ô∏è‚É£ **User presses the mouse button** ‚Üí `onmousedown` fires  
2Ô∏è‚É£ **User releases the mouse button** ‚Üí `onmouseup` fires  
3Ô∏è‚É£ **Click action completes** ‚Üí `onclick` fires  

---

## **üìå Example 1: Logging Each Mouse Event**
```html




<button id="myButton">Click Me</button>





```
‚úî **Opens the console and click the button to see the event sequence.**

---

## **üìå Example 2: Changing Button Color on Press and Release**
```html




<button id="myButton">Press Me</button>





```
‚úî The **button changes color when pressed and released**, and **shows an alert on full click**.

---

## **üìå Example 3: Using `addEventListener()` (Recommended)**
Instead of assigning events directly, **use `addEventListener()`** for better structure and flexibility.

```html
<button id="myBtn">Click Me</button>


```
‚úî **Keeps HTML clean and allows multiple event listeners on the same element.**

---

## **üìå Summary**
| **Event** | **Triggers When...** | **Common Uses** |
|-----------|----------------------|----------------|
| `onmousedown` | The mouse button is **pressed down**. | Start animations, change styles. |
| `onmouseup` | The mouse button is **released**. | Stop animations, reset styles. |
| `onclick` | A full click event occurs (**mousedown + mouseup**). | Execute functions on click. |

üöÄ **Using mouse events dynamically improves interactivity and user experience on web pages!**

question: The addEventListener() method
answer:
### **Using `addEventListener()` to Attach Events in JavaScript** The **`addEventListener()`** method is the preferred way to attach event handlers to elements because it: ‚úî **Does not overwrite existing event handlers** ‚úî **Allows multiple event handlers for the same event** ‚úî **Can be applied to any DOM object (not just HTML elements)** ‚úî **Provides better control over event bubbling** ‚úî **Keeps JavaScript separate from HTML for cleaner code** --- ## **üìå Example 1: Adding an Event Listener to a Button** ```html

``` ‚úî Clicking the button **displays the current date and time** inside `

`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Adding Multiple Event Listeners to the Same Element** Unlike `onclick`, which **overwrites previous event handlers**, `addEventListener()` allows **multiple handlers** for the same event. ```html ``` ‚úî **Both alerts will fire when the button is clicked**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Removing an Event Listener (`removeEventListener()`)** You can **remove an event listener** using `removeEventListener()`, but **the function must be named** (anonymous functions cannot be removed). ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking "Click Me" **shows an alert**. ‚úî Clicking "Remove Click Event" **disables the click functionality**. --- ## **üìå Example 4: Adding an Event Listener to the Window Object** You can attach event listeners **not just to HTML elements but also to the `window` object**. ```js window.addEventListener("resize", function() { console.log("Window resized!"); }); ``` ‚úî This **logs a message whenever the window is resized**. --- ## **üìå Controlling Event Bubbling and Capturing** By default, event listeners use **bubbling** (events propagate from child to parent). You can **set the third parameter to `true` to use capturing**. ```html

``` ‚úî When clicking **Child**, the **Parent event fires first** due to **capturing mode (`true`)**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `addEventListener(event, function)` | Attaches an event without overwriting existing ones. | `element.addEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | `removeEventListener(event, function)` | Removes an event listener (**requires named function**). | `element.removeEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | `window.addEventListener(event, function)` | Adds an event to the window object. | `window.addEventListener("resize", myFunction);` | üöÄ **Using `addEventListener()` is the best way to attach events dynamically, allowing multiple handlers and better control over event flow!**

subject: DOM event listener
question: Syntax
answer:
### **Using `addEventListener(event, function, useCapture)` in JavaScript** The **`addEventListener()`** method allows you to attach an event handler to an element. It provides flexibility by: ‚úî **Allowing multiple event handlers on the same element** ‚úî **Providing access to the event object** ‚úî **Controlling event bubbling or capturing** --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js element.addEventListener(event, function, useCapture); ``` - **`event`** ‚Üí The type of event (`"click"`, `"mouseover"`, `"keydown"`, etc.). - **`function`** ‚Üí The function to execute when the event occurs. - **`useCapture` (optional, default = `false`)** ‚Üí - `true` ‚Üí Event captured **during capturing phase** (from parent to child). - `false` ‚Üí Event captured **during bubbling phase** (child to parent). --- ## **üìå Example 1: Adding a Click Event Using an Anonymous Function** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **shows an alert message**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Using an External Named Function** Instead of using an anonymous function, you can refer to a **named function**. ```html ``` ‚úî Keeps the code **organized and reusable**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Handling an Event with the Event Object** When an event occurs, an **event object** is passed to the function, containing details about the event. ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **displays the event type (`click`) and the clicked element (`BUTTON`)**. --- ## **üìå Example 4: Controlling Event Bubbling vs. Capturing** By default, event listeners **use bubbling (`false`)**, but you can enable **capturing (`true`)**. ```html
``` ‚úî Since **capturing (`true`)** is enabled, clicking the button **first triggers the parent event, then the child**. --- ## **üìå Example 5: Removing an Event Listener** To **remove an event listener**, you need to use a **named function**. ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking "Click Me" **triggers the alert**, but clicking "Remove Event" **disables further clicks**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Feature** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | **Attach an Event** | Adds an event without overwriting existing ones. | `element.addEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | **Remove an Event** | Removes an event listener (**requires a named function**). | `element.removeEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | **Event Object** | Provides event details like `target`, `type`, etc. | `event.target.tagName;` | | **Bubbling (`false`)** | Events propagate **from child to parent** (default). | `element.addEventListener("click", func, false);` | | **Capturing (`true`)** | Events propagate **from parent to child**. | `element.addEventListener("click", func, true);` | üöÄ **Using `addEventListener()` makes event handling flexible, efficient, and interactive!**

question: Add Many Event Handlers to the Same Element
answer:
### **Using `addEventListener()` to Attach Multiple Events to an Element** The **`addEventListener()`** method allows you to: ‚úî **Attach multiple event handlers to the same element** without overwriting previous ones. ‚úî **Add multiple types of events** (e.g., `click`, `mouseover`, `mouseout`) to a single element. ‚úî **Provide better event management** compared to `onclick`, which replaces previous event handlers. --- ## **üìå Attaching Multiple Event Listeners to the Same Element** You can **add multiple event handlers of the same type** to an element. ### **Example 1: Assigning Multiple `click` Handlers** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **executes both `myFunction()` and `mySecondFunction()`**. --- ## **üìå Adding Different Events to the Same Element** You can **assign multiple event types** (e.g., `mouseover`, `click`, `mouseout`) to a single element. ### **Example 2: Handling Multiple Event Types** ```html

Hover or Click Me!

``` ‚úî **Hovering over** the text turns it **blue**. ‚úî **Clicking** the text **increases its font size**. ‚úî **Moving the mouse out** restores the original **black color**. --- ## **üìå Removing an Event Listener (`removeEventListener()`)** You can **remove an event listener**, but the function **must be named**. ### **Example 3: Removing an Event Listener** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking "Click Me" **triggers the alert**. ‚úî Clicking "Remove Event" **disables the click event**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Feature** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | **Multiple Events on the Same Element** | Allows multiple event handlers of the **same event type** on an element. | `element.addEventListener("click", func1); element.addEventListener("click", func2);` | | **Different Events on the Same Element** | Adds different event types to the same element. | `element.addEventListener("mouseover", func1); element.addEventListener("mouseout", func2);` | | **Remove an Event Listener** | Requires a **named function** to remove. | `element.removeEventListener("click", func);` | üöÄ **Using `addEventListener()` provides better control over events, making interactions more dynamic and flexible!**

question: Add an Event Handler to the window Object
answer:
### **Using `addEventListener()` on Various DOM Objects in JavaScript** The **`addEventListener()`** method allows you to attach events not only to HTML elements but also to other **DOM objects** such as: ‚úî The **`window` object** ‚úî The **document** ‚úî The **XMLHttpRequest object** ‚úî Any object that supports events --- ## **üìå Example 1: Detecting Window Resize** You can use the **`resize` event** on the `window` object to **detect changes in window size**. ```html

Resize the window to see the effect.

``` ‚úî When the user **resizes the browser window**, it updates the **width and height** dynamically. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Using `addEventListener()` on `document`** The `document` object can also listen for events such as `DOMContentLoaded`, which fires when the page **fully loads**. ```html ``` ‚úî Logs **"Page fully loaded!"** when the **HTML content is fully parsed**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Using `addEventListener()` with `XMLHttpRequest`** The `XMLHttpRequest` object supports events like `"load"`, `"error"`, and `"progress"`. ```html ``` ‚úî Fetches data from an API and logs it when **loading completes**. --- ## **üìå Example 4: Handling Key Presses in `window`** You can capture **keyboard events** using `window.addEventListener()`. ```html

``` ‚úî Displays **the key pressed** in real-time. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Target Object** | **Event Example** | **Usage** | |------------------|------------------|----------| | `window` | `"resize"`, `"scroll"`, `"keydown"` | Detect window interactions. | | `document` | `"DOMContentLoaded"`, `"click"` | Handle document-wide events. | | `XMLHttpRequest` | `"load"`, `"error"` | Monitor HTTP requests. | | **Any DOM Element** | `"click"`, `"mouseover"`, `"change"` | Add interactions to elements. | üöÄ **Using `addEventListener()` on different DOM objects enhances interactivity and dynamic behavior on web pages!**

subject: DOM event listener
question: Passing Parameters
answer:
### **Passing Parameters in `addEventListener()` Using an Anonymous Function** By default, when you assign an event listener using `addEventListener()`, the event-handling function is called **without arguments**. If you need to pass parameters, you must **wrap the function call inside an anonymous function**. --- ## **üìå Syntax: Using an Anonymous Function to Pass Arguments** ```js element.addEventListener("click", function() { myFunction(p1, p2); }); ``` ‚úî This ensures that `myFunction(p1, p2)` is only **executed when the event occurs**, instead of running immediately. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Passing Parameters to a Function on Click** ```html

``` ‚úî Clicking the button **displays a name and age** inside the paragraph. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Passing the Clicked Element as a Parameter** ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking **each button** changes its own text to `"Clicked!"`. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Using `this` to Pass the Event Target** If you want to pass the **clicked element itself**, use `this`. ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking the button **alerts its own text content**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | **Direct Function Reference** | Runs without parameters. | `element.addEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | **Anonymous Function with Parameters** | Calls function with arguments. | `element.addEventListener("click", function(){ myFunction(p1, p2); });` | | **Using `this`** | Passes the clicked element. | `element.addEventListener("click", function(){ myFunction(this); });` | üöÄ **Using an anonymous function inside `addEventListener()` allows dynamic event handling with arguments!**

subject: DOM event listener
question: Event Bubbling or Event Capturing?
answer:
### **Event Propagation in JavaScript: Bubbling vs. Capturing** Event propagation determines **the order in which events fire** when multiple elements are nested. The **two phases** of event propagation are: 1Ô∏è‚É£ **Bubbling (default, `false`)** ‚Üí The **inner element's event fires first**, then propagates outward to the parent elements. 2Ô∏è‚É£ **Capturing (`true`)** ‚Üí The **outer element's event fires first**, then propagates inward to the target element. --- ## **üìå Understanding Event Propagation** Imagine the following HTML structure: ```html

Click me!

``` If the user clicks on `

`, should **`

` or `

` handle the event first**? The answer depends on **bubbling** or **capturing**. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Event Bubbling (Default)** ```html

Click me!

``` ‚úî Clicking on `

` first triggers `"Paragraph Clicked!"`, then **bubbles up** to `

` showing `"Div Clicked!"`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Event Capturing (Setting `true`)** To **capture the event from the parent first**, set the `useCapture` parameter to `true`. ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking on `

` now **first triggers `"Div Clicked!"`**, then `"Paragraph Clicked!"`. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Stopping Propagation** If you want to **prevent an event from propagating** further, use `event.stopPropagation()`. ```html ``` ‚úî Clicking on `

` **only triggers `"Paragraph Clicked!"`**, stopping the event from reaching `

`. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Propagation Type** | **Order of Event Execution** | **Default?** | **Example** | |--------------------|----------------------|------------|-----------| | **Bubbling (`false`)** | **Inner to Outer** (`

` ‚Üí `

`) | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.addEventListener("click", func, false);` | | **Capturing (`true`)** | **Outer to Inner** (`
` ‚Üí `

`) | ‚ùå No | `element.addEventListener("click", func, true);` | | **Stopping Propagation** | Stops event from moving further | ‚ùå No | `event.stopPropagation();` | üöÄ **Understanding event propagation helps manage event flow efficiently, preventing unintended interactions!**

subject: DOM event listener
question: The removeEventListener() method
answer:
### **Removing Event Listeners in JavaScript Using `removeEventListener()`** The **`removeEventListener()`** method allows you to remove an event listener that was previously attached using **`addEventListener()`**. This is useful when you want to stop event execution dynamically. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js element.removeEventListener("event", functionName); ``` - **`event`** ‚Üí The type of event to remove (e.g., `"click"`, `"mousemove"`, `"keydown"`). - **`functionName`** ‚Üí The **same function reference** used in `addEventListener()`. ‚úî **Important:** The function **must be named** to be removable. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Removing a `mousemove` Event** ```html

Move your mouse over this area to see coordinates.

``` ‚úî **While moving the mouse, coordinates are displayed.** ‚úî **Clicking "Stop Tracking" removes the event listener, stopping updates.** --- ## **üìå Example 2: Removing a Click Event from a Button** ```html ``` ‚úî **Clicking "Disable Click Event" stops the button from showing alerts.** --- ## **üìå Example 3: Why Anonymous Functions Cannot Be Removed** ```js element.addEventListener("click", function() { alert("Hello"); }); element.removeEventListener("click", function() { alert("Hello"); }); ``` ‚ùå **The event is not removed** because the function references are different. ‚úî **Solution:** Use a **named function** instead. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Feature** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | **Removing an Event Listener** | Works only with named functions. | `element.removeEventListener("click", myFunction);` | | **Anonymous Functions** | Cannot be removed. | ‚ùå `element.removeEventListener("click", function() {});` | | **Stopping Dynamic Events** | Useful for stopping tracking, clicks, keypresses, etc. | `removeEventListener("mousemove", showCoords);` | üöÄ **Use `removeEventListener()` to dynamically control event execution, improving interactivity and efficiency!**

subject: DOM event listener
question: The addEventListener() object interface (no w3)
answer:
### **Using `handleEvent()` in `addEventListener()`**

The **`addEventListener()`** method usually takes a **function** as an event handler. However, it can also accept an **object** that has a `handleEvent(event)` method. This allows for **object-oriented event handling** where an object itself can manage multiple events.

---

## **üìå Syntax Using `handleEvent`**
```js
element.addEventListener("eventType", {
    handleEvent: function(event) {
        // Handle event here
    }
});
```
- The object **must have a `handleEvent()` method**.
- When the event occurs, **`handleEvent()` is automatically called**.

---

## **üìå Example 1: Using an Object with `handleEvent()`**
```html




<button id="myButton">Click Me</button>





```
‚úî **Clicking the button triggers `handleEvent()` inside the object.**

---

## **üìå Example 2: Using a Constructor Function**
You can create **custom objects** to manage events dynamically.

```html




<button id="myButton">Click Me</button>





```
‚úî **Clicking the button changes its text to `"Clicked!"`**.

---

## **üìå Example 3: Using a Class with `handleEvent()`**
A **better way** to manage event listeners **is with ES6 classes**.

```html




<button id="myButton">Click Me</button>





```
‚úî The **button text changes when clicked**, and the handler is **an object instead of a function**.

---

## **üìå When to Use `handleEvent()` Instead of a Regular Function**
| **Feature** | **Function in `addEventListener()`** | **Object with `handleEvent()`** |
|------------|----------------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Ease of use** | Simple and widely used | More structured for complex scenarios |
| **Handles multiple events** | Requires multiple functions | Can be managed inside one object |
| **State Management** | No built-in state | Can store state inside object properties |
| **Reusability** | Can reuse functions | More reusable for multiple event types |

---

## **üìå Summary**
‚úî **`handleEvent()` allows objects to act as event listeners**, making them more structured and reusable.  
‚úî **Useful for managing multiple event types inside a single object**.  
‚úî **Works well with ES6 classes**, allowing stateful event handling.  

üöÄ **Using `handleEvent()` is useful for structured, object-oriented event management in JavaScript!**

### **Understanding the HTML DOM Node Tree in JavaScript** The **HTML DOM (Document Object Model)** represents an HTML document as a **tree structure**, where everything in the document is a **node**. This allows JavaScript to **access, create, modify, and delete nodes dynamically**. --- ## **üìå Types of Nodes in the DOM** | **Node Type** | **Description** | |--------------|----------------| | **Document Node** | Represents the **entire document**. (`document`) | | **Element Nodes** | Represent **HTML elements** (e.g., `
`, `

`, `

`). | | **Text Nodes** | Contain **text inside an element** (e.g., `"Hello World"` inside `

Hello World

`). | | **Attribute Nodes** (**Deprecated**) | Represent attributes (e.g., `class="example"`). Attributes are now accessed as properties. | | **Comment Nodes** | Represent **comments** in the HTML document (e.g., ``). | --- ## **üìå Example: HTML DOM Node Tree** Consider the following HTML: ```html

Hello World!

``` The **DOM node tree** for this document: ``` Document (document) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ (Element Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ (Element Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ
(Element Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ

(Element Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ "Hello World!" (Text Node) ``` ‚úî The `document` is the **root node** containing **element nodes**, which contain **text nodes**. --- ## **üìå Accessing Nodes Using JavaScript** JavaScript allows you to **traverse** the DOM and access different types of nodes. ### **Example 1: Accessing an Element Node** ```js var element = document.getElementById("container"); console.log(element.nodeName); // Output: DIV console.log(element.nodeType); // Output: 1 (Element Node) ``` ‚úî `nodeName` returns the **tag name**. ‚úî `nodeType` returns the **numeric node type** (`1 = Element Node`). --- ## **üìå Creating, Modifying, and Deleting Nodes** ### **Example 2: Creating and Appending a New Node** ```js var newParagraph = document.createElement("p"); // Create a

element var textNode = document.createTextNode("This is new!"); // Create a text node newParagraph.appendChild(textNode); // Append text to

document.getElementById("container").appendChild(newParagraph); // Add to

``` ‚úî **Dynamically adds** `

This is new!

` inside `
`. --- ### **Example 3: Removing a Node** ```js var parent = document.getElementById("container"); var child = document.querySelector("p"); // Select first

parent.removeChild(child); // Remove the paragraph ``` ‚úî This **removes** the first `

` inside `

`. --- ## **üìå Special Nodes: Comments and Attributes** ### **Example 4: Adding a Comment Node** ```js var comment = document.createComment("This is a comment"); document.body.appendChild(comment); ``` ‚úî Creates and **appends a comment** (``) inside ``. ### **Example 5: Modifying an Attribute Node (Modern Approach)** ```js document.getElementById("container").setAttribute("class", "newClass"); ``` ‚úî **Sets the `class` attribute** on `
`. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Node Type** | **Example** | **JavaScript Access** | |--------------|------------|----------------------| | **Document Node** | The entire page | `document` | | **Element Node** | `

`, `

` | `document.getElementById("id")` | | **Text Node** | `"Hello World"` inside `

` | `.textContent` | | **Attribute Node** | `class="example"` (**deprecated**) | `.setAttribute("class", "newClass")` | | **Comment Node** | `` | `document.createComment("text")` | üöÄ **Understanding the HTML DOM Node Tree allows full control over web page structure using JavaScript!**

subject: DOM navigation
question: Node Relationships
answer:
### **Understanding Parent, Child, and Sibling Nodes in the HTML DOM Tree** In the **DOM (Document Object Model)**, elements are arranged in a **hierarchical tree structure**, where each element is related to others through **parent-child** and **sibling** relationships. --- ## **üìå DOM Node Relationships** | **Term** | **Description** | |----------|---------------| | **Root Node** | The **top node** of the document tree (``). | | **Parent Node** | A node **that contains other nodes** inside it. | | **Child Nodes** | Nodes **directly inside** a parent node. | | **Sibling Nodes** | Nodes **on the same level**, sharing the same parent. | --- ## **üìå Example: DOM Tree Structure** ### **HTML Code** ```html DOM Tutorial

DOM Lesson one

Hello world!

``` ### **DOM Hierarchy Representation** ``` Document (document) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ (Root Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ (Child of ) ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ (Child of <head>) ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ "DOM Tutorial" (Text Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ <body> (Child of <html>) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ <h1> (Child of <body>) ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ "DOM Lesson one" (Text Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ <p> (Child of <body>) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ "Hello world!" (Text Node) ``` --- ## **üìå Understanding the Node Relationships** - **`<html>` is the root node** and has **two children**: `<head>` and `<body>`. - **`<head>` has one child**: `<title>`. - **`<title>` has one text child**: `"DOM Tutorial"`. - **`<body>` has two children**: `<h1>` and `<p>`. - **`<h1>` has one text child**: `"DOM Lesson one"`. - **`<p>` has one text child**: `"Hello world!"`. - **`<h1>` and `<p>` are siblings**, sharing `<body>` as their parent. --- ## **üìå JavaScript Methods for Traversing the DOM** You can **navigate the DOM tree** using various properties. | **Property** | **Description** | |-------------|----------------| | `element.parentNode` | Returns the **parent node** of an element. | | `element.childNodes` | Returns a **NodeList** of an element's children (including text nodes). | | `element.children` | Returns a **collection of child elements** (ignores text nodes). | | `element.firstChild` | Returns the **first child** (includes text nodes). | | `element.firstElementChild` | Returns the **first child element** (excludes text nodes). | | `element.lastChild` | Returns the **last child** (includes text nodes). | | `element.lastElementChild` | Returns the **last child element** (excludes text nodes). | | `element.nextSibling` | Returns the **next sibling** (includes text nodes). | | `element.nextElementSibling` | Returns the **next sibling element** (excludes text nodes). | | `element.previousSibling` | Returns the **previous sibling** (includes text nodes). | | `element.previousElementSibling` | Returns the **previous sibling element** (excludes text nodes). | --- ## **üìå Example 1: Getting the Parent Node** ```html <p id="myParagraph">Hello World!</p> <script> let p = document.getElementById("myParagraph"); console.log(p.parentNode.nodeName); // Output: BODY </script> ``` ‚úî Returns `"BODY"` because `<p>` is inside `<body>`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Getting All Child Elements** ```html <div id="container"> <p>First paragraph</p> <p>Second paragraph</p> </div> <script> let container = document.getElementById("container"); console.log(container.children.length); // Output: 2 console.log(container.firstElementChild.innerHTML); // Output: "First paragraph" console.log(container.lastElementChild.innerHTML); // Output: "Second paragraph" </script> ``` ‚úî **`children` ignores text nodes** and only counts actual elements. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Getting Sibling Nodes** ```html <h1 id="heading">Heading</h1> <p>Paragraph 1</p> <p id="target">Paragraph 2</p> <script> let p2 = document.getElementById("target"); console.log(p2.previousElementSibling.nodeName); // Output: "P" </script> ``` ‚úî Finds the **previous sibling** of `<p id="target">`, which is another `<p>`. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Concept** | **Example Usage** | |-------------|----------------| | **Get Parent Node** | `element.parentNode` | | **Get Child Nodes** | `element.childNodes` (includes text) | | **Get Child Elements** | `element.children` (only elements) | | **Get First Child** | `element.firstChild` / `element.firstElementChild` | | **Get Last Child** | `element.lastChild` / `element.lastElementChild` | | **Get Next Sibling** | `element.nextSibling` / `element.nextElementSibling` | | **Get Previous Sibling** | `element.previousSibling` / `element.previousElementSibling` | üöÄ **Mastering the DOM hierarchy allows you to manipulate and traverse the document effectively!**</body></html>

subject: DOM navigation
question: Navigating Between Nodes
answer:
### **Navigating the DOM Using Node Properties in JavaScript** The HTML **DOM (Document Object Model)** provides several **node properties** that allow you to **traverse the node tree** and access elements dynamically. --- ## **üìå Node Properties for Traversing the DOM** | **Property** | **Description** | |-------------|----------------| | `parentNode` | Returns the **parent node** of an element. | | `childNodes[nodenumber]` | Returns a **NodeList** of all child nodes (including text nodes). | | `firstChild` | Returns the **first child node** (including text nodes). | | `lastChild` | Returns the **last child node** (including text nodes). | | `nextSibling` | Returns the **next sibling node** (including text nodes). | | `previousSibling` | Returns the **previous sibling node** (including text nodes). | **Important:** `childNodes`, `firstChild`, `lastChild`, `nextSibling`, and `previousSibling` include **text nodes** (whitespace between elements is counted as a text node). To work only with **elements**, use: - `children` instead of `childNodes` - `firstElementChild` instead of `firstChild` - `lastElementChild` instead of `lastChild` - `nextElementSibling` instead of `nextSibling` - `previousElementSibling` instead of `previousSibling` --- ## **üìå Example: Basic HTML Structure** ```html

Title

First paragraph

Second paragraph

Third paragraph

``` --- ## **üìå Example 1: Getting the Parent Node** ```js let target = document.getElementById("target"); console.log(target.parentNode.nodeName); // Output: DIV ``` ‚úî Returns `"DIV"` because `

` is inside `

`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Accessing Child Nodes** ```js let container = document.getElementById("container"); console.log(container.childNodes.length); // Output: Number of all child nodes (including text) console.log(container.childNodes[1].nodeName); // Output: "H2" ``` ‚úî `childNodes` includes **text nodes**, so the actual elements may not be at expected indexes. **Use `children` to get only elements**: ```js console.log(container.children.length); // Output: 3 (Only elements) console.log(container.children[0].nodeName); // Output: "H2" ``` --- ## **üìå Example 3: Getting the First and Last Child** ```js console.log(container.firstChild.nodeName); // Output: #text (due to whitespace) console.log(container.lastChild.nodeName); // Output: #text (due to whitespace) ``` ‚úî **Use `firstElementChild` and `lastElementChild` to ignore text nodes**: ```js console.log(container.firstElementChild.nodeName); // Output: "H2" console.log(container.lastElementChild.nodeName); // Output: "P" ``` --- ## **üìå Example 4: Getting Next and Previous Sibling** ```js let target = document.getElementById("target"); console.log(target.nextSibling.nodeName); // Output: #text (whitespace) console.log(target.previousSibling.nodeName); // Output: #text (whitespace) ``` ‚úî **Use `nextElementSibling` and `previousElementSibling` to skip text nodes**: ```js console.log(target.nextElementSibling.nodeName); // Output: "P" console.log(target.previousElementSibling.nodeName); // Output: "P" ``` --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Includes Text Nodes?** | **Example Usage** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `parentNode` | No | `element.parentNode` | | `childNodes[n]` | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.childNodes[1]` | | `firstChild` | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.firstChild` | | `lastChild` | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.lastChild` | | `nextSibling` | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.nextSibling` | | `previousSibling` | ‚úÖ Yes | `element.previousSibling` | | `children` | ‚ùå No (Only elements) | `element.children[1]` | | `firstElementChild` | ‚ùå No | `element.firstElementChild` | | `lastElementChild` | ‚ùå No | `element.lastElementChild` | | `nextElementSibling` | ‚ùå No | `element.nextElementSibling` | | `previousElementSibling` | ‚ùå No | `element.previousElementSibling` | üöÄ **Understanding DOM navigation helps in dynamically modifying and interacting with HTML elements efficiently!**

subject: DOM navigation
question: Child Nodes and Node Values
answer:
### **Understanding Text Nodes in the DOM and How to Access Text Content** A **common mistake** in DOM processing is assuming that an **element node** directly contains text. In reality: ‚úî **An element node (``, `<p>`, `<h1>`, etc.) contains a text node.** ‚úî **The actual text is stored inside a `text node` as its child.** --- ## **üìå Example: Understanding Text Nodes** Consider the following HTML: ```html <title id="demo">DOM Tutorial ``` Here, `` is an **element node**, but `"DOM Tutorial"` is a **text node** inside it. The **DOM structure looks like this:** ``` <title> (Element Node) ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ "DOM Tutorial" (Text Node) ``` --- ## **üìå How to Access the Text Node Value** | **Method** | **Description** | **Example** | |------------|----------------|-------------| | `element.innerHTML` | Retrieves the inner HTML content (text included). | `element.innerHTML` | | `element.firstChild.nodeValue` | Retrieves the **text content** inside the first child (text node). | `element.firstChild.nodeValue` | | `element.childNodes[0].nodeValue` | Another way to get the **first text node** content. | `element.childNodes[0].nodeValue` | --- ## **üìå Example 1: Accessing the Text Content** ```html <!DOCTYPE html> <html> <head> <title id="demo">DOM Tutorial

``` ‚úî **Retrieves `"DOM Tutorial"` using `innerHTML` and displays it inside `

`**. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Using `firstChild.nodeValue`** ```js var myTitle = document.getElementById("demo").firstChild.nodeValue; console.log(myTitle); // Output: "DOM Tutorial" ``` ‚úî This **accesses the text node's value directly**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Using `childNodes[0].nodeValue`** ```js var myTitle = document.getElementById("demo").childNodes[0].nodeValue; console.log(myTitle); // Output: "DOM Tutorial" ``` ‚úî This **accesses the first child node**, which is the **text node**. --- ## **üìå Why Use `firstChild.nodeValue` Instead of `innerHTML`?** | **Method** | **Best Use Case** | |------------|------------------| | `innerHTML` | When working with **both text and HTML elements inside an element**. | | `firstChild.nodeValue` | When **you specifically want the text content only** (avoids reading HTML tags). | | `childNodes[0].nodeValue` | Alternative way to access the first child text node. | üöÄ **Understanding text nodes in the DOM helps avoid errors when extracting text content dynamically!**

### **Accessing the Full Document Using `document.body` and `document.documentElement`** JavaScript provides **two special properties** that allow access to different parts of an HTML document: | **Property** | **Description** | |-------------|----------------| | `document.body` | Returns the `` element (excluding ``). | | `document.documentElement` | Returns the **entire document**, including ``. | --- ## **üìå Example: Accessing the ``** ```html DOM Example

``` ‚úî Retrieves **everything inside ``**, including elements and text. --- ## **üìå Example: Accessing the Entire Document (``)** ```js console.log(document.documentElement.innerHTML); ``` ‚úî Logs the **entire HTML document**, including `` and ``. --- ## **üìå Example: Modifying the Body** ```js document.body.style.backgroundColor = "lightblue"; ``` ‚úî Changes the **background color** of the whole page. --- ## **üìå Example: Getting the Page Scroll Position** These properties are useful when handling **scroll events**. ```js console.log("Page Scroll Y:", document.documentElement.scrollTop); // Scroll position (Y-axis) console.log("Page Height:", document.documentElement.scrollHeight); // Full height of document ``` ‚úî Useful for **infinite scrolling** or **detecting when the user reaches the bottom** of a page. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Property** | **Description** | **Example** | |-------------|----------------|-------------| | `document.body` | Accesses the **``** element only. | `document.body.innerHTML` | | `document.documentElement` | Accesses the **entire document (``)**. | `document.documentElement.innerHTML` | | `.scrollTop` | Gets **vertical scroll position**. | `document.documentElement.scrollTop` | | `.scrollHeight` | Gets **total height of document**. | `document.documentElement.scrollHeight` | üöÄ **Using `document.body` and `document.documentElement` allows you to manipulate and interact with the full webpage dynamically!**

answer:
### **Creating and Appending New Elements in the DOM Using JavaScript** JavaScript allows you to **dynamically create new elements**, add text to them, and insert them into an existing HTML document. This is useful for dynamically updating content without modifying the original HTML. --- ## **üìå Steps to Create and Append an Element** 1Ô∏è‚É£ **Create a new element** ‚Üí `document.createElement("tag")` 2Ô∏è‚É£ **Create a text node** ‚Üí `document.createTextNode("text content")` 3Ô∏è‚É£ **Append the text node to the new element** ‚Üí `element.appendChild(textNode)` 4Ô∏è‚É£ **Append the new element to an existing element** ‚Üí `parent.appendChild(newElement)` --- ## **üìå Example 1: Creating and Adding a New `

` Element** ```html

This is a container.
``` ‚úî Clicking the **"Add Paragraph"** button inserts **`

subject: DOM nodes
question: Creating new HTML Elements - insertBefore()
answer:
### **Using `insertBefore()` to Insert Elements in JavaScript** By default, **`appendChild()`** adds a new element **as the last child** of a parent. If you want to insert an element **before an existing element**, use **`insertBefore(newElement, referenceElement)`**. --- ## **üìå Syntax** ```js parentElement.insertBefore(newElement, referenceElement); ``` - **`parentElement`** ‚Üí The element containing the new and reference elements. - **`newElement`** ‚Üí The element you want to insert. - **`referenceElement`** ‚Üí The element before which the new element is inserted. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Inserting an Element Before an Existing Element** ```html

This is a paragraph.

This is another paragraph.

``` ‚úî Clicking **"Insert Before First Paragraph"** inserts `"This is new."` **before** the first `

` inside `

`. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Inserting a List Item at a Specific Position** ```html
  • Item 1
  • Item 2
``` ‚úî Clicking **"Insert Before Item 2"** inserts `"New Item"` **before** `"Item 2"` in the list. --- ## **üìå Example 3: Inserting an Element at the Beginning** If you want to insert a new element **at the beginning of a parent**, use: ```js parentElement.insertBefore(newElement, parentElement.firstChild); ``` ‚úî This ensures that the **new element is always the first child**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Action** | **Example** | |------------|------------|-------------| | `appendChild(newElement)` | Adds **as the last child** | `parent.appendChild(newElement);` | | `insertBefore(newElement, referenceElement)` | Inserts **before an existing element** | `parent.insertBefore(newElement, reference);` | üöÄ **Using `insertBefore()` allows precise control over where new elements are added dynamically!**

question: The HTMLCollection Object

### **Understanding `getElementsByTagName()` and `HTMLCollection` in JavaScript** The **`getElementsByTagName()`** method returns an **HTMLCollection**, which is an **array-like list** of elements matching the specified tag name. --- ## **üìå Key Features of `HTMLCollection`** ‚úî **Live Collection** ‚Üí Automatically updates if elements are added/removed. ‚úî **Indexed Access** ‚Üí Elements can be accessed using `collection[index]`. ‚úî **Looping** ‚Üí Can be looped using `for` or `forEach` (after converting to an array). --- ## **üìå Example 1: Selecting All `

` Elements** ```html

` elements to blue**. --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Method** | **Returns** | **Supports `forEach()`?** | |------------|------------|----------------| | `getElementsByTagName("p")` | **HTMLCollection** (Live) | ‚ùå No (Convert to array first) | | `querySelectorAll("p")` | **NodeList** (Static) | ‚úÖ Yes | üöÄ **Using `getElementsByTagName()` allows you to efficiently select and modify multiple elements dynamically!**

question: An HTMLCollection is NOT an array!
answer:
### **Understanding `HTMLCollection` and Its Limitations Compared to Arrays** An **`HTMLCollection`** is **not an array**, but it behaves **like an array** in some ways: ‚úî **You can loop through it using a `for` loop**. ‚úî **You can access elements using an index (`collection[index]`)**. ‚ùå **You cannot use array methods like `push()`, `pop()`, or `join()` directly**. --- ## **üìå Example 1: Looping Through an `HTMLCollection`** ```html

` elements dynamically. --- ## **üìå Example 2: Converting `HTMLCollection` to an Array** Since `HTMLCollection` **does not support array methods**, you can **convert it to an array** using `Array.from()`. ```html

Box 1
Box 2
Box 3
``` ‚úî Converts `HTMLCollection` to an **array**, allowing **`forEach()` and other array methods**. --- ## **üìå Example 3: `HTMLCollection` Does Not Support Array Methods** ```js var items = document.getElementsByTagName("p"); // ‚ùå This will NOT work: items.push("New Item"); // Error: push() is not a function items.pop(); // Error: pop() is not a function items.join(", "); // Error: join() is not a function ``` ‚úî **Convert to an array before using array methods:** ```js var itemsArray = Array.from(items); itemsArray.push("New Item"); console.log(itemsArray.join(", ")); ``` --- ## **üìå Summary** | **Feature** | **`HTMLCollection`** | **Array** | |------------|----------------|------------| | Indexed Access (`collection[0]`) | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úÖ Yes | | Looping (`for` or `forEach`) | ‚úÖ Yes (for loop) ‚ùå No (`forEach` without conversion) | ‚úÖ Yes | | Array Methods (`push()`, `pop()`, `join()`) | ‚ùå No | ‚úÖ Yes | | Conversion to Array | ‚úÖ Use `Array.from()` | N/A | üöÄ **Convert `HTMLCollection` to an array when you need advanced array methods!**

question: The HTML DOM NodeList Object
answer:
### **Understanding `NodeList` in JavaScript** A **`NodeList`** is a **collection of nodes** extracted from an HTML document. It is **similar to an `HTMLCollection`**, but with key differences. --- ## **üìå Key Differences Between `NodeList` and `HTMLCollection`** | Feature | `NodeList` | `HTMLCollection` | |------------|--------------|----------------| | **Returned by** | `querySelectorAll()`, `childNodes` | `getElementsByTagName()`, `getElementsByClassName()` | | **Supports `forEach()`** | ‚úÖ Yes (except in very old browsers) | ‚ùå No | | **Live Collection?** | ‚ùå No (Static) | ‚úÖ Yes (Updates dynamically) | | **Indexed Access (`[i]`)** | ‚úÖ Yes | ‚úÖ Yes | | **Convert to Array?** | ‚úÖ Yes, use `Array.from()` | ‚úÖ Yes, use `Array.from()` | üöÄ **`NodeList` is preferred when using `querySelectorAll()` because it supports `forEach()`.** --- ## **üìå Example 1: Selecting All `

` Elements Using `querySelectorAll()`** ```html

Paragraph 1
